facts.text: The 1st respondent is a municipality governed by the provisions of the Municipal Boroughs Act, Bombay Act XVIII of 1925.
The appellant is one of the 32 councillors constituting the municipality.
The last general election to the municipality took place on the 7th May 1951.
The term of the councillors was three years computed from the date of the first general meeting held after the general election, in this case the 10th July 1951.
In the first general meeting on 10th July 1951, the 4th and 5th respondents were elected President and Vice-President respectively of the municipality for a term of three years.
The Act was amended by Bombay Act XXXV of 1954, under which the term of office of the councillors was extended from 3 to 4 years ending on the 9th July 1955.

As the term of respondents 4 and 5 was to expire at the end of three years from 10th July 1951, and the term of the municipality was extended by one year, vacancies occurred to be filled by fresh election of President and Vice-President.

The Collector called a special general meeting of the municipality to be held on the 30th July 1954 to elect President and Vice-President for the remaining period of the quadrennium. The Collector nominated the Prant Officer (District Deputy Collector) to preside.

On 30th July 1954, the Prant Officer under instructions from the Collector adjourned the meeting to 3rd August 1954 without transacting any business. The 3rd respondent raised a point of order against the adjournment, which was overruled. All 32 councillors were present.
Special general meeting held on 3rd August 1954. Appellant raised point of order that under the Act a President could not be elected for a term less than a year. Objection overruled.
13 out of 32 councillors present, including appellant, walked out. Remaining 19 councillors elected 2nd respondent as President for the remaining period of the quadrennium.

Immediately after, another meeting under presidency of newly elected President (2nd respondent) for election of Vice-President. Appellant raised same point of order, overruled. Six councillors including appellant walked out. Remaining elected 3rd respondent as Vice-President. All 32 present.
Appellant moved High Court of Bombay under Art. 226 for writ of quo warranto or other writ against 2nd and 3rd respondents restraining them from office.
High Court dismissed petition on 23rd August 1954, holding election not illegal.
Appellant applied for leave to appeal to SC, rejected. Special leave granted by SC on 3rd September 1954.

Bombay Legislature enacted Act LIV of 1954, published 14th October 1954, amending s19 retrospectively from date of Act XXXV of 1954 (11th May 1954), validating elections held between those dates for terms less than one year.

legal_issues.text: Whether the meeting of the 3rd August 1954 had been validly held (adjourned properly, called by Collector, notice under s35(3) given).
Whether the President and Vice-President having been elected for the remaining period of the quadrennium (less than one year) had been validly elected under s19.

petitioner_arguments.text: Meeting of 3rd August invalid as not properly adjourned from 30th July, not called by Collector, no written notice under s35(3) served/published.
Election of President invalid, thus meeting for VP under his presidency invalid.
Election violates s19 as term less than one year.
Amending Act LIV of 1954 does not affect pending proceedings retrospectively.

respondent_arguments.text: President and VP could be elected for term less than one year as s19 subject to s23(1A); anyway validated by Act LIV of 1954.
Presiding officer had power to adjourn; meeting of 3rd Aug treatable as fresh meeting called by Collector; irregularities cured by s57.
Appellant did not object to adjournment on 30th July; no right to writ as no injury.
Walk out of 13 councillors does not invalidate meeting; no quorum issue.

court_reasoning.text: Meeting of 3rd Aug valid as called by Collector under instructions, Prant Officer authorized; all 32 councillors present and notified orally with 3 clear days notice, time/place/business indicated; s35(3) directory per s57, no prejudice as all present.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Irregularities in notice service/publication mere irregularities not vitiating proceedings under s57; public presence not obligatory.

court_reasoning.text: Walk out voluntary, does not render meeting invalid; councillors could not elect own chairman if presiding officer refuses.
s19 issue cured by Act LIV of 1954, retrospective from 11 May 1954, validates all such elections explicitly including pending proceedings; no saving for litigation implied.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature intended to apply to all cases; clear language affects pending proceedings.

holdings.text: Meeting of 3rd August 1954 validly held; no illegality in election of 2nd and 3rd respondents.
Elections valid notwithstanding s19 as amended retrospectively by Act LIV of 1954.

precedents_cited.case_name: The King v. The General Commissioners of Income-tax for Southampton Ex parte W. M. Singer
precedents_cited.relevance: Retrospective statute can affect pending proceedings if clear language used, no express saving needed.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mukerjee, Official Receiver v. Ramratan Kuer
precedents_cited.relevance: Retrospective amendment applies to pending appeals if intended for all cases of description, no implied saving.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act, 1925
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs term of office, calling/presiding meetings, notice requirements, curing irregularities; s19 prohibits term less than one year unless amended.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Act XXXV of 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Extended municipal term to 4 years ending 9 July 1955.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Act LIV of 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Amended s19 to allow election for residue less than one year; retrospectively validated elections from 11 May 1954.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for High Court writ petition.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; orders of High Court affirmed, though not for same reasons. Elections of 2nd and 3rd respondents as President and Vice-President held valid.

key_quotes.text: "No resolution of a municipality deemed invalid on account of any irregularity in the service of notice upon any councillor or member provided that the proceedings of the municipality were not prejudicially affected by such irregularity."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets s57 as making notice provisions directory.

key_quotes.text: "I cannot accept the contention of the applicant that an enactment can only take away vested rights of action for which legal proceedings have been commenced if there are in the enactment express words to that effect."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From cited precedent; supports retrospective effect on pending cases.

key_quotes.text: "The amendments made by this Act shall be deemed to have come into force on the date on which the Bombay District Municipal and Municipal Boroughs (Amendment) Act, 1954, came into force... and all elections... shall be deemed to be valid."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes Act LIV s3 validating impugned elections retrospectively.
